description: This protocol describes how to set up an embryo collection cage in order to collect fruit fly eggs and how to relabily dispense a consistent number of eggs into food medium for development.
keywords: Drosophila, embryo collection cage, egg squirt
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Place an apple-agar plate in the embryo collection cage to provide a substrate for egg laying. Prior to adding the plate, smear a small quantity of yeast paste (dry yeast mixed with water to a peanut-butter like consistency) onto the centre of the apple-agar. The addition of yeast will encourage egg laying. Water soaked absorbent cotton wool is also added to the cage to provide moisture.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place an apple-agar plate in the embryo collection cage to provide a substrate for egg laying. Prior to adding the plate, smear a small quantity of yeast paste (dry yeast mixed with water to a peanut-butter like consistency) onto the centre of the apple-agar. The addition of yeast will encourage egg laying. Water soaked absorbent cotton wool is also added to the cage to provide moisture.

components.data: Add fly population to cage and place cage at 25±1 °C in a 12 h:12h light:dark cycle for 24 hours.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add fly population to cage and place cage at 25±1 °C in a 12 h:12h light:dark cycle for 24 hours.

components.data: Check the surface of the apple-agar plate for eggs. If If there are too few eggs, flies may require a longer habituation period. Replace with a fresh apple-agar plate, re-soak the cotton wool and leave the fly population in cage for a further 24 hours.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Check the surface of the apple-agar plate for eggs. If If there are too few eggs, flies may require a longer habituation period. Replace with a fresh apple-agar plate, re-soak the cotton wool and leave the fly population in cage for a further 24 hours.

components.data: Take egg laden apple-agar plate from the cage and remove remaining yeast paste and any dead flies from the agar surface.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Take egg laden apple-agar plate from the cage and remove remaining yeast paste and any dead flies from the agar surface.

components.data: Submerge the apple-agar plate in 1x PBS and gently dislodge eggs from the agar surface with a fine paintbrush– most eggs will be found on the outer edge of the agar. While suspended in PBS, transfer the eggs to a falcon tube and leave for 5 min, allowing the eggs to sink to the bottom of solution.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Submerge the apple-agar plate in 1x PBS and gently dislodge eggs from the agar surface with a fine paintbrush– most eggs will be found on the outer edge of the agar. While suspended in PBS, transfer the eggs to a falcon tube and leave for 5 min, allowing the eggs to sink to the bottom of solution.

components.data: Cut the bottom 4mm off a p1000 filtered pipette tip, and use this to draw 1 mL of ‘eggy solution’, taken from the bottom of the falcon tube. Transfer this to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube and allow to settle. When drawing up solution a more consistent number of eggs is achieved by snap-releasing the pipette plunger rather than by gentle-release.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cut the bottom 4mm off a p1000 filtered pipette tip, and use this to draw 1 mL of ‘eggy solution’, taken from the bottom of the falcon tube. Transfer this to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube and allow to settle. When drawing up solution a more consistent number of eggs is achieved by snap-releasing the pipette plunger rather than by gentle-release.

components.data: Cut the bottom 4 mm off a p20 filtered pipette tip. Set the pipette to a desired volume and draw this from the bottom of the microcentrifuge tube, again using the snap-release pipetting method. With practice a consistent number of eggs can be obtained, a volume of 5μL will produce 102±4 eggs.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cut the bottom 4 mm off a p20 filtered pipette tip. Set the pipette to a desired volume and draw this from the bottom of the microcentrifuge tube, again using the snap-release pipetting method. With practice a consistent number of eggs can be obtained, a volume of 5μL will produce 102±4 eggs.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 7 of Drosophila embryo collection

components.data: Dispense collected eggs onto food source and leave to develop until required for experiments.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dispense collected eggs onto food source and leave to develop until required for experiments.
